Title:
Multiple-marker phylogeny and morphological evidence reveal a
new genus and two species in Steccherinaceae (Polyporales,
Basidiomycota)
Keywords:
Molecular phylogeny, polypores, taxonomy, wood-inhabiting
fungi
Abstract:
Two new poroid wood-inhabiting fungi, Coniferitrullella
densopora gen. & sp. nov. and Flabellophora subglobosa sp. nov., are
proposed and described from East Asia based on ITS, nrLSU, tef1 and rpb2
molecular phylogeny and morphological characteristics. C. densopora is
characterized by a laterally stipitate basidiocarp with flabelliform to
semicircular pileus, hirtellous pileal surface with appressed coarse
hair and concentrically zoned and sulcate, tiny pores (1012 per mm), a
dimitic hyphal system, absence of cystidia, short clavate basidia and
thin-walled, smooth, cylindrical to allantoid basidiospores. F.
subglobosa is characterized by a sessile or laterally stipitate
basidiocarp, velutinate to glabrous pileal surface concentrically zoned
and indistinctly sulcate, tiny pores (1115 per mm), a dimitic hyphal
system, absence of cystidia, guttulate, short, clavate to subglobose
basidia and thin-walled, broadly ellipsoid to subglobose basidiospores.
Phylogenetic analyses based on a four-marker dataset were performed
using maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods. The new genus
Coniferitrullella formed an independent clade with strong support in
Steccherinaceae and the two new species C. densopora and F. subglobosa
get full support respectively. The distinguishing characters of the the
new genus and species as well as allied genera are discussed and a key
to species of Flabellophora was provided.
